div2.stage:
Enter Leonato gouernour of Messina, Innogen his wife, Hero
his daughter, and Beatrice his neece, with a
messenger.

sp.speaker: Leonato.
sp.p:
I Learn in this letter, that don Peter of Arragon
comes this night to Messina.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
He is very near by this, he was not three
leagues off when I left him.

sp.speaker: Leona.
sp.p: How many gentlemen have you lost in this action?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: But few of any sort, and none of name.

sp.speaker: Leona.
sp.p:
A victory is twice itself, when the achiever brings
home full numbers: I find here, that don Peter hath bestowed
much honour on a young Florentine called Claudio.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Much deserved on his part, and equally remembered
by don Pedro, he hath borne himself beyond the promise of
his age, doing in the figure of a lamb, the feats of a lion, he hath
indeed better bettered expectation than you must expect of me
to tell you how.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
He hath an uncle here in Messina will be very much
glad of it.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
I have already delivered him letters, and there
appears much joy in him, even so much, that joy could not show
itself modest enough, without a badge of bitterness.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Did he break out into tears?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: In great measure.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
A kind overflow of kindness, there are no faces truer
than those that are so washed, how much better is it to weep at
joy, than to joy at weeping?

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p:
I pray you, is Signior Mountanto returned from the
wars or no?

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.p:
I know none of that name, lady, there was none
such in the army of any sort.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: What is he that you ask for niece?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p: My cousin means Signior Benedicke of Padua.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: O he is returned, and as pleasant as ever he was.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p:
He set up his bills here in Messina, and challenged
Cupid at the Flight, and my uncles fool reading the challenge
subscribed for Cupid, and challenged him at the Burbolt: I
pray you, how many hath he killed and eaten in these wars?
but how many hath he killed? For indeed I promised to eat all
of his killing.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
Faith niece you tax Signior Benedicke too much,
but he will be meet with you, I doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: He hath done good service lady in these wars.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
You had musty victual, and he hath helped to eat it,
he is a very valiant trencher man, he hath an excellent
stomach.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: And a good soldier too, lady.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
And a good soldier to a Lady, but what is he to a
Lord?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
A lord to a lord, a man to a man, stuffed with all
honourable virtues.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
It is so indeed, he is no less than a stuffed man, but for
the stuffing well, we are all mortal.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
You must not, sir, mistake my niece, there is a kind
of merry war betwixt Signior Benedicke and her, they never
meet but there is a skirmish of wit between them.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Alas he gets nothing by that, in our last conflict, four of his
five wits went halting off, and now is the whole man governed
with one, so that if he have wit enough to keep himself warm,
let him bear it for a difference between himself and his horse,
for it is all the wealth that he hath left, to be known a reasonable
creature, who is his companion now? he hath every month
a new sworn brother.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Very easily possible, he wears his faith but as the
fashion of his hat, it ever changes with the next block.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: I see lady the gentleman is not in your books.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
No, if he were, I would burn my study, but I pray
you who is his companion? is there no young squarer now that
will make a voyage with him to the devil?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
O Lord, he will hang upon him like a disease, he is
sooner caught than the pestilence, and the taker runs presently
mad, God help the noble Claudio, if he have caught the
Benedict, it will cost him a thousand pound ere he be cured.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: I will hold friends with you Lady.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Do good friend.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You will never run mad niece.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: No, not till a hot January.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Don Pedro is approached.

div2.stage:
Enter don Pedro, Claudio, Benedicke, Balthasar
and Iohn the bastard.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p:
Good signior Leonato, are you come to meet your
trouble: the fashion of the world is, to avoid cost, and you
encounter it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
never came trouble to my house, in the likeness of
your grace, for trouble being gone, comfort should remain:
but when you depart from me, sorrow abides, and happiness
takes his leave.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p:
You embrace your charge too willingly: I think
this is your daughter.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: Her mother hath many times told me so.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Were you in doubt sir that you asked her?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: Signior Benedicke, no, for then were you a child.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p:
You have it full Benedicke, we may guess by this,
what you are, being a man, truly the Lady fathers herself:
be happy Lady, for you are like an honourable father.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p:
If Signior Leonato be her father, she would not have
his head on her shoulders for all Messina as like him as she is.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I wonder that you will still be talking, signior
Benedicke, nobody marks you.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: What my dear lady Disdain! are you yet living?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p:
Is it possible Disdain should die, while she hath such
meet food to feed it, as signior Benedicke? Courtesy itself
must convert to Disdain, if you come in her presence.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Then is courtesy a turncoat, but it is certain I am
loved of all Ladies, only you excepted: and I would I could
find in my heart that I had not a hard heart, for truly I love
none.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
A dear happiness to women, they would else have
been troubled with a pernicious suitor, I thank God and my
cold blood, I am of your humour for that, I had rather hear
my dog bark at a crow, than a man swear he loves me.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
God keep your Ladyship still in that mind, so some
Gentleman or other shall scape a predestinate scratched face.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Scratching could not make it worse, if it were such
a face as yours were.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Well, you are a rare parrot teacher.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: A bird of my tongue, is better than a beast of yours.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
I would my horse had the speed of your tongue, and
so good a continuer, but keep your way in Gods name, I have
done.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
You always end with a jades trick, I know you of
old.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p:
That is the sum of all: Leonato, signior Claudio,
and signior Benedicke, my dear friend Leonato, hath invited
you all, I tell him we shall stay here, at the least a month, and
he heartily prays some occasion may detain us longer, I dare
swear he is no hypocrite, but prays from his heart.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
If you swear, my lord, you shall not be forsworn,
let me bid you welcome, my lord, being reconciled to the
Prince your brother: I owe you all duty.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
I thank you, I am not of many words, but I thank
you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Please it your grace lead on?

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: Your hand Leonato, we will go together.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Benedicke, didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: I noted her not, but I looked on her,

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Is she not a modest young lady?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Do you question me as an honest man should do,
for my simple true judgment? or would you have me speak
after my custom, as being a professed tyrant to their sex?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: No, I pray thee speak in sober judgment.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Why in faith methinks she is too low for a hie praise,
too brown for a fair praise, and too little for a great praise,
only this commendation I can afford her, that were she other
than she is, she were unhandsome, and being no other, but as she
is, I do not like her.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p:
Thou thinkest I am in sport, I pray thee tell me
truly how thou likest her.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Would you buy her that you enquire after her?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: Can the world buy such a jewel?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Yea, and a case to put it into, but speak you this
with a sad brow? or do you play the flouting iacke, to tell us
Cupid is a good Hare-finder, and Vulcan a rare Carpenter:
Come, in what key shall a man take you to go in the song?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p:
In mine eye, she is the sweetest Lady that ever I
looked on.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
I can see yet without spectacles, and I see no such
matter: there is her cousin, if she were not possessed with a fury,
exceeds her as much in beauty, as the first of May doth the
last of December: but I hope you have no intent to turn
husband, have you?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p:
I would scarce trust myself, though I had sworn
the contrary, if Hero would be my wife.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
Is it come to this? In faith hath not the world one
man but he will wear his cap with suspicion? shall I never
see a bachelor of three score again? go to In faith and thou wilt
needs thrust thy neck into a yoke, wear the print of it, and
sigh away sundays: look, don Pedro is returned to seek you.

div2.stage: Enter don Pedro, Iohn the bastard.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p:
What secret hath held you here, that you followed
not to Leonatoes?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: I would your Grace would constrain me to tell.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: I charge thee on thy allegiance.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
You hear, Count Claudio, I can be secret as a dumb
man, I would have you think so (but on my allegiance,
mark you this, on my allegiance) he is in love, with who? Now
that is your Graces part: mark how short his answer is, with
Hero Leonatoes short daughter.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: If this were so, so were it uttered.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
Like the old tale, my Lord, it is not so, nor it was
not so: but indeed, God forbid it should be so.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p:
If my passion change not shortly, God forbid it
should be otherwise.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p:
Amen, if you love her, for the Lady is very well
worthy.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: You speak this to fetch me in, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: By my troth I speak my thought.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: And in faith, my Lord, I spoke mine.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
And by my two faiths and troths, my Lord, I
spoke mine.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: That I love her, I feel.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: That she is worthy, I know.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
That I neither feel how she should be loved, nor
know how she should be worthy, is the opinion that fire can
not melt out of me, I will die in it at the stake.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p:
Thou wast ever an obstinate heretic in the
despite of Beauty.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
And never could maintain his part, but in the force
of his will

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
That a woman conceived me, I thank her: that she
brought me up I likewise give her most humble thanks: but
that I will have a recheat winded in my forehead, or hang my
bugle in an invisible baldrick, all women shall pardon me:
because I will not do them the wrong to mistrust any, I will
do myself the right to trust none: and the fine is, (for the
which I may go the finer,) I will live a bachelor.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: I shall see thee ere I die, look pale with love.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
With anger, with sickness, or with hunger, my
Lord, not with love: prove that ever I lose more blood with
love than I will get again with drinking, pick out mine eyes
with a Ballad-makers pen, and hang me up at the door of a
brothel house for the sign of blind Cupid.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p:
Well, if ever thou dost fall from this faith, thou wilt
prove a notable argument.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
If I do, hang me in a bottle like a Cat, and shoot at
me, and he that hits me, let him be clapped on the shoulder, and
called Adam.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p:
Well, as time shall try: in time the savage bull doth
bear the yoke.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
The savage bull may, but if ever the sensible
Benedicke bear it, pluck off the bulls horns, and set them in my
forehead, and let me be vildly painted, and in such great
letters as they write, here is good horse to hire: let them signify
under my sign, here you may see Benedicke the married
man.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p:
If this should ever happen, thou wouldst be horn
mad.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p:
Nay, if Cupid have not spent all his quiver in Venice,
thou wilt quake for this shortly.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: I look for an earthquake too then.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p:
Well, you will temporise with the hours, in the
mean time, good signior Benedicke, repair to Leonatoes,
commend me to him, and tell him I will not fail him at
supper, for indeed he hath made great preparation.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
I have almost matter enough in me for such an
Embassage, and so I commit you.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: To the tuition of God: from my house if I had it.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: The sixth of July: your loving friend Benedicke.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
Nay mock not, mock not, the body of your
discourse is sometime guarded with fragments, and the guards
are but slightly basted on neither, ere you flout old ends any
further, examine your conscience, and so I leave you.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p:
My liege, your Highness now may do me
good.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.l: My love is thine to teach, teach it but how,
And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn
Any hard lesson that may do thee good.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Hath Leonato any son, my lord?

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.l: No child but Hero, she is his only heir:
Dost thou affect her Claudio?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: O my lord,
When you went onward on this ended action,
I looked upon her with a soldiers eye,
That liked, but had a rougher task in hand,
Than to drive liking to the name of love:
But now I am returned, and that war-thoughts,
Have left their places vacant: in their rooms,
Come thronging soft and delicate desires,
All prompting me how fair young Hero is,
Saying I liked her ere I went to wars.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.l: Thou wilt be like a lover presently,
And tire the hearer with a book of words,
If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it,
And I will break with her and with her father,
And thou shalt have her: wast not to this end,
That thou beganst to twist so fine a story?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: How sweetly you do minister to love,
That know loves grief by his complexion!
But lest my liking might too sudden seem,
I would have salved it with a longer treatise.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.l: What need the bridge much broader than the flood?
The fairest grant is the necessity:
Look what will serve is fit: it is once, thou lovest,
And I will fit thee with the remedy,
I know we shall have revelling tonight,
I will assume thy part in some disguise,
And tell fair Hero I am Claudio,
And in her bosom I will unclasp my heart,
And take her hearing prisoner with the force
And strong encounter of my amorous tale:
Then after, to her father will I break,
And the conclusion is, she shall be thine,
In practise let us put it presently.

div2.stage: Enter Leonato and an old man brother to Leonato

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
How now brother, where is my cousin your son, hath
he provided this music?

sp.speaker: Old
sp.p:
He is very busy about it, but brother, I can tell you
strange news that you yet dreamt not of.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Are they good?

sp.speaker: Old
sp.p:
As the events stamps them, but they have a good
cover: they show well outward, the prince and Count Claudio
walking in a thick pleached alley in mine orchard, were thus
much overheard by a man of mine: the prince discovered to
Claudio that he loved my niece your daughter, and meant to
acknowledge it this night in a dance, and if he found her
accordant, he meant to take the present time by the top, and
instantly break with you of it.

sp.speaker: Leo
sp.p: Hath the fellow any wit that told you this?

sp.speaker: Old
sp.p:
A good sharp fellow, I will send for him, and question
him yourself.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
No, no, we will hold it as a dream till it appear itself:
but I will acquaint my daughter withal, that she may be the
better prepared for an answer, if peradventure this be true: go
you and tell her of it: cousins, you know what you have to do,
O I cry you mercy friend, go you with me and I will use your
shill: good cousin have a care this busy time.

div2.stage: Enter sir Iohn the bastard, and Conrade his companion.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
What the good year my lord, why are you thus out of
measure sad?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
There is no measure in the occasion that breeds,
therefore the sadness is without limit.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: You should hear reason.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: And when I have heard it, what blessing brings it?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: If not a present remedy, at least a patient sufferance.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
I wonder that thou (being as thou sayst, thou art, born
under Saturne) goest about to apply a moral medicine, to a
mortifying mischief: I cannot hide what I am: I must be sad
when I have cause, and smile at no man's jests, eat when I have
stomach, and wait for no man's leisure: sleep when I am
drowsy, and tend on no man's business, laugh when I am merry, and
claw no man in his humour.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Yea but you must not make the full show of this till
you may do it without controlment, you have of late stood
out against your brother, and he hath taken you newly into his
grace, where it is impossible you should take true root, but by
the fair weather that you make yourself, it is needful that you
frame the season for your own harvest.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
I had rather be a canker in a hedge, than a rose in his
grace, and it better fits my blood to be disdained of all, than to
fashion a carriage to rob love from any: in this (though I cannot
be said to be a flattering honest man) it must not be denied but I
am a plain dealing villain, I am trusted with a mussel, and
enfranchised with a clog, therefore I have decreed, not to sing
in my cage: if I had my mouth I would bite: if I had my liberty
I would do my liking: in the mean time, let me be that I am,
and seek not to alter me.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Can you make no use of your discontent?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: I make all use of it, for I use it only,
Who comes here? what news Borachio?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
I came yonder from a great supper, the prince your
brother is royally entertained by Leonato, and I can give you
intelligence of an intended marriage.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
Will it serve for any model to build mischief on? what
is he for a fool that betroths himself to unquietness?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Marry it is your brothers right hand.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: Who, the most exquisite Claudio?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: even he.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
A proper squire, and who, and who, which way looks
he?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Marry one Hero the daughter and heir of Leonato.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
A very forward March-chick, how came you to
this?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Being entertained for a perfumer, as I was smoking a
musty room, comes me the prince and Claudio, hand in
hand in sad conference: I whipped me behind the arras, and there
heard it agreed upon that the prince should woo Hero for
himself, and having obtained her, give her to Count Claudio.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
Come, come, let us thither, this may prove food to my
displeasure, that young start-up hath all the glory of my overthrow:
if I can cross him any way, I bless myself every way,
you are both sure, and will assist me.

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.p: To the death my Lord.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
Let us to the great supper, their cheer is the greater
that I am subdued, would the cook were of my mind, shall we
go prove What is to be done?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: We will wait upon your lordship.

div2.stage:
Enter Leonato, his brother, his wife, Hero his daughter, and
Beatrice his neece, and a kinsman.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: Was not count Iohn here at supper?

sp.speaker: brother
sp.p: I saw him not.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.p:
How tartly that gentleman looks, I never can see
him but I am heart-burned an hour after.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p: He is of a very melancholy disposition.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.p:
He were an excellent man that were made just in
the mid-way between him and Benedick, the one is too like an
image and says nothing, and the other too like my ladies eldest
son, evermore tattling.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
Then half signior Benedickes tongue in Count
Iohns mouth, and half Count Iohns melancholy in Signior
Benedickes face.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.p:
With a good leg and a good foot uncle, and
money enough in his purse, such a man would win any
woman in the world if he could get her good will.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
By my troth niece thou wilt never get thee a
husband, if thou be so shrewd of thy tongue.

sp.speaker: brother
sp.p: In faith she is too cursed.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.p:
Too cursed is more than cursed, I shall lessen
Gods sending that way, for it is said, God sends a cursed cow
short horns, but to a cow too cursed, he sends none.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
So, by being too cursed, God will send you no
horns.

sp.speaker: Beatrice.
sp.p:
Just, if he send me no husband, for the which
blessing, I am at him upon my knees every morning and evening:
Lord, I could not endure a husband with a beard on his face, I
had rather lie in the woollen!

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: You may light on a husband that hath no beard.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.p:
What should I do with him, dress him in my
apparel and make him my waiting gentlewoman? he that hath a
beard, is more than a youth: and he that hath no beard, is less
than a man: and he that is more than a youth, is not for me, and
he that is less than a man, I am not for him, therefore I will
even take sixpence in earnest of the Berrord, and lead his
apes into hell.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: Well then, go you into hell.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.p:
No but to the gate, and there will the devil meet
me like an old cuckold with horns on his head, and say, get
you to heaven Beatrice, get you to heaven, here is no place for
you maids, so deliver I up my apes and away to saint Peter: for
the heavens, he shows me where the Bachelors sit, and there
live we as merry as the day is long.

sp.speaker: brother
sp.p: Well niece, I trust you will be ruled by your father.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.p:
Yes faith, it is my cousins duty to make curtsy and
say, father, as it please you: but yet for all that cousin, let him be a
handsome fellow, or else make another curtsy, and say, father,
as it please me.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
Well niece, I hope to see you one day fitted with a
husband.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.p:
Not till God make men of some other metal than
earth, would it not grieve a woman to be overmastered with
a piece of valiant dust? To make an account of her life to a clod
of wayward marvel? No uncle, I will none: Adams sons are my
brethren, and truly I hold it a sin to match in my kindred.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
Daughter, remember what I told you, if the prince
do solicit you in that kind, you know your answer.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.p:
The fault will be in the music cousin, if you be
not wooed in good time: if the prince be too important, tell
him there is measure in everything, and so dance out the
answer, for hear me Hero, wooing, wedding, and repenting, is
as a Scotch jig, a measure, and a cinquepace: the first suite is
hot and hasty like a Scotch jig (and full as fantastical) the
wedding mannerly modest (as a measure) full of state and
ancientry, and then comes Repentance, and with his bad legs
falls into the cinquepace faster and faster, till he sink into his
grave.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: Cousin you apprehend passing shrewdly.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.p:
I have good eye uncle, I can see a church by
day-light.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
The revellers are entering brother, make good
room.

div2.stage:
Enter prince, Pedro, Claudio, and Benedicke, and Balthaser,
or dumb Iohn.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: Lady will you walk about with your friend?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p:
So, you walk softly, and look sweetly, and say
nothing, I am yours for the walk, and especially when I walk away.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: With me in your company.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p: I may say so when I please.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: And when please you to say so?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p:
When I like your favour, for God defend the lute
should be like the case.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p:
My visor is Philemons roof, within the house is
Ioue.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p: Why then your visor should be thatched.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: Speak low if you speak loue.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Well, I would you did like me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
So would not I for your own sake, for I have
many ill qualities.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Which is one?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I say my prayers aloud.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: I love you the better, the hearers may cry Amen.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: God match me with a good dancer.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
And God keep him out of my sight when the
dance is done: answer Clarke.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: No more words, the Clarke is answered.

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.p: I know you well enough, you are signior Anthonio.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: At a word I am not.

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.p: I know you by the waggling of your head.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: To tell you true, I counterfeit him.

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.p:
You could never do him so ill well, unless you
were the very man: here is his dry hand up and down, you
are he, you are he.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: At a word, I am not.

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.p:
Come, come, do you think I do not know you by
your excellent wit? can virtue hide itself? go to, mumm, you
are he, graces will appear, and there is an end.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Will you not tell me who told you so?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: No, you shall pardon me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Nor will you not tell me who you are?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Not now.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
That I was disdainful, and that I had my good wit
out of the hundred merry tales: well, this was signior Benedick
that said so.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I am sure you know him well enough.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Not I, believe me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Did he never make you laugh?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: I pray you what is he?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Why he is the princes jester, a very dull fool, only his
gift is, in devising impossible slanders, none but Libertines
delight in him, and the commendation is not in his wit, but in
his villainy, for he both pleases men and angers them, and then
they laugh at him, and beat him: I am sure he is in the Fleet,
I would he had boarded me.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
When I know the Gentleman, I will tell him what you
say.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Do, do, he will but break a comparison or two on me,
which peradventure, (not marked, or not laughed at) strikes him
into melancholy, and then there is a partridge wing saved, for the
fool will eat no supper that night: we must follow the leaders.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: In every good thing.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will leave them at the
next turning.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
Sure my brother is amorous on Hero, and hath
withdrawn her father to break with him about it: the Ladies
follow her, and but one visor remains.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.p: And that is Claudio, I know him by his bearing.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: Are not you signior Benedicke?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: You know me well, I am he.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
Signior, you are very near my brother in his love, he
is enamoured on Hero, I pray you dissuade him from her, she
is no equal for his birth, you may do the part of an honest
man in it.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: How know you he loves her?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: I heard him swear his affection.

sp.speaker: Borac.
sp.p: So did I too, and he swore he would marry her tonight.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: Come let us to the banquet.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Thus answer I in name of Benedicke,
But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio:
It is certain so, the Prince woos for himself,
Friendship is constant in all other things,
Save in the office and affairs of love:
Therefore all hearts in love use their own tongues.
Let every eye negotiate for itself,
And trust no Agent: for Beauty is a witch,
Against whose charms, faith melteth into blood:
This is an accident of hourly proof,
Which I mistrusted not: farewell therefore Hero.

sp.speaker: Benedicke
sp.p: Count Claudio.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: Yea, the same.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Come, will you go with me?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
even to the next willow, about your own business,
county: what fashion will you wear the garland of? About
your neck, like an Usurers chain? or under your arm, like a
Lieutenants scarf? you must wear it one way, for the prince
hath got your Hero.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: I wish him joy of her.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
Why that is spoken like an honest Drover, so they
sell bullocks: but did you think the Prince would have
served you thus?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: I pray you leave me.

sp.speaker: Benedicke
sp.p:
Ho now you strike like the blind man, it was the
boy that stole your meat, and you will beat the post.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: If it will not be, I will leave you.

sp.speaker: Benedicke
sp.p:
Alas poor hurt fowl, now will he creep into
sedges: but that my Lady Beatrice should know me, and not
know me: the princes fool! ha, it may be I go under that
title because I am merry: yea but so I am apt to do myself
wrong: I am not so reputed, it is the base (though bitter)
disposition of Beatrice, that puts the world into her person, and so
gives me out: well, I will be revenged as I may.

div2.stage:
Enter the Prince, Hero, Leonato, Iohn and Borachio,
and Conrade.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: Now signior, where is the Count, did you see him?

sp.speaker: Benedicke
sp.p:
Troth my lord, I have played the part of Lady
Fame, I found him here as melancholy as a Lodge in a
Warren, I told him, and I think I told him true, that your grace
had got the goodwill of this young Lady, and I offered him my
company to a willow tree, either to make him a garland, as
being forsaken, or to bind him up a rod, as being worthy to be
whipped.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: To be whipped, what is his fault?

sp.speaker: Benedicke
sp.p:
The flat transgression of a Schoolboy, who
being overjoyed with finding a birds nest, shows it his
companion, and he steals it.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p:
Wilt thou make a trust a transgression? the transgression
is in the stealer.

sp.speaker: Benedicke
sp.p:
Yet it had not been amiss the rod had been
made, and the garland too, for the garland he might have worn
himself, and the rod he might have bestowed on you, who
(as I take it) have stolen his birds nest.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p:
I will but teach them to sing, and restore them to the
owner.

sp.speaker: Benedicke
sp.p:
If their singing answer your saying, by my faith
you say honestly.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p:
The lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you, the
Gentleman that danced with her, told her she is much wronged by
you.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
O she misused me past the endurance of a block:
an oak but with one green leaf on it, would have answered
her: my very visor began to assume life, and scold with her:
she told me, not thinking I had been myself, that I was the
Princes jester, that I was duller than a great thaw, huddling
jest upon jest, with such impossible conveyance upon me, that
I stood like a man at a mark, with a whole army shooting
at me: she speaks poniards, and every word stabs: if her
breath were as terrible as her terminations, there were no
living near her, she would infect to the north star: I would
not marry her, though she were endowed with all that Adam
had left him before he transgressed, she would have made
Hercules have turned spit, yea, and have cleft his club to make the
fire too: come, talk not of her, you shall find her the infernal
Ate in good apparel, I would to God some scholar would
conjure her, for certainly, while she is here, a man may live
as quiet in hell, as in a sanctuary, and people sin upon
purpose, because they would go thither, so indeed all disquiet,
horror, and perturbation follows her.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: Look here she comes.

sp.speaker: Benedicke
sp.p:
Will your grace command me any service to the
worlds end? I will go on the slightest errand now to the
Antipodes that you can devise to send me on: I will fetch you a
tooth-picker now from the furthest inch of Asia: bring you
the length of Prester Iohns foot: fetch you a hair off the great
Chams beard: do you any embassage to the Pygmies, rather
than hold three words conference, with this harpy, you have
no employment for me?

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: None, but to desire your good company.

sp.speaker: Benedicke
sp.p:
O God sir, here is a dish I love not, I cannot
endure my Lady Tongue.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p:
Come Lady, come, you have lost the heart of signior
Benedicke.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.p:
Indeed my Lord, he lent it me awhile, and I gave
him use for it, a double heart for his single one, marry once
before he won it of me, with false dice, therefore your grace
may well say I have lost it.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p:
You have put him down Lady, you have put him
down.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.p:
So I would not he should do me, my Lord, lest I
should prove the mother of fools: I have brought Count
Claudio, whom you sent me to seek.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: Why how now Count, wherefore are you sad?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: Not sad my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: How then? sick?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: Neither, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.p:
The Count is neither sad, nor sick, nor merry,
nor well: but civil Count, civil as an orange, and something
of that jealous complexion.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p:
In faith Lady, I think your blazon to be true, though
I will be sworn, if he be so, his conceit is false: here Claudio, I
have wooed in thy name, and fair Hero is won, I have broke
with her father, and his good will obtained, name the day of
marriage, and God give thee joy.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
Count take of me my daughter, and with her my
fortunes: his grace hath made the match, and all grace say
Amen to it.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.p: Speak Count, it is your cue.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p:
Silence is the perfectest Herault of joy, I were but
little happy if I could say, how much? Lady, as you are mine,
I am yours, I give away myself for you, and dote upon the
exchange.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Speak cousin, or (if you cannot) stop his mouth with a
kiss, and let not him speak neither.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: In faith lady you have a merry heart.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p:
Yea my lord I thank it, poor fool it keeps on the
windy side of Care, my cousin tells him in his ear that he is in
her heart

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: And so she doth cousin.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Good Lord for alliance: thus goes every one to the
world but I, and I am sun-burnt, I may sit in a corner and cry,
heigh ho for a husband.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I would rather have one of your fathers getting: hath
your grace never a brother like you? your father got excellent
husbands if a maid could come by them.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Will you have me? lady.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p:
No my lord, unless I might have another for
working days, your grace is too costly to wear every day: but I
beseech your grace pardon me, I was born to speak all mirth,
and no matter.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Your silence most offends me, and to be merry, best
becomes you, for out a question, you were born in a merry
hour.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p:
No sure my lord, my mother cried, but then there
was a star danced, and under that was I born, cousins God
give you joy.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
Niece, will you look to those things I told you
of?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I cry you mercy uncle, by your graces pardon.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: By my troth a pleasant spirited lady.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
There is little of the melancholy element in her my
lord, she is never sad, but when she sleeps, and not ever sad then:
for I have heard my daughter say, she hath often dreamt of
unhappiness, and waked herself with laughing.

sp.speaker: Pedro
sp.p: She cannot endure to hear tell of a husband.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
O by no means, she mocks all her wooers out of
suit.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: She were an excellent wife for Benedick.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
O Lord, my lord, if they were but a week married,
they would talk themselves mad.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
County Claudio, when mean you to go to
church?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
Tomorrow my lord, Time goes on crutches, till Love
have all his rites.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
Not till monday, my dear son, which is hence a
just seven-night, and a time too brief too, to have all things
answer my mind.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Come, you shake the head at so long a breathing,
but I warrant thee Claudio, the time shall not go dully by us, I
will in the interim, undertake one of Hercules labours, which is,
to bring Signior Benedick and the lady Beatrice into a mountain
of affection, the one with the other, I would fain have it a
match, and I doubt not but to fashion it, if you three will but
minister such assistance as I shall give you direction.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
My lord, I am for you, though it cost me ten nights
watchings.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: And I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: And you too gentle Hero?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p:
I will do any modest office, my lord, to help my cousin
to a good husband.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
And Benedicke is not the unhopefullest husband
that I know: thus far can I praise him, he is of a noble strain,
of approved valour, and confirmed honesty, I will teach you
how to humour your cousin, that she shall fall in love with
Benedicke, and I, with your two helps, will so practise on
Benedicke, that in despite of his quick wit, and his queasy
stomach, he shall fall in love with Beatrice: if we can do this,
Cupid is no longer an Archer, his glory shall be ours, for we are
the only love-gods, go in with me, and I will tell you my
drift.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
It is so, the Count Claudio shall marry the daughter
of Leonato.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p: Yea my lord, but I can cross it.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
Any bar, any cross, any impediment, will be
medicinable to me, I am sick in displeasure to him, and whatsoever
comes athwart his affection, ranges evenly with mine, how
canst thou cross this marriage?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Not honestly my lord, but so covertly, that no
dishonesty shall appear in me.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: Show me briefly how.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
I think I told your lordship a year since, how much
I am in the favour of Margaret, the waiting gentlewoman to
Hero.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: I remember.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
I can at any unseasonable instant of the night, appoint
her to look out at her ladies chamber window.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: What life is in that to be the death of this marriage?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
The poison of that lies in you to temper, go you to
the prince your brother, spare not to tell him, that he hath
wronged his honour in marrying the renowned Claudio, whose
estimation do you mightily hold up to a contaminated stale,
such a one as Hero.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: What proof shall I make of that?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Proof enough, to misuse the prince, to vex Claudio,
to undo Hero, and kill Leonato, look you for any other
issue?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: Only to despite them I will endeavour anything.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Go then, find me a meet hour, to draw don Pedro and
the Count Claudio alone, tell them that you know that Hero
loves me, intend a kind of zeal both to the prince and Claudio
(as in love of your brothers honour who hath made this match)
and his friends reputation, who is thus like to be cozened with
the semblance of a maid, that you have discovered thus: they will
scarcely believe this without trial: offer them instances which
shall bear no less likelihood, than to see me at her chamber
window, hear me call Margaret Hero, hear Marg. term me
Claudio, and bring them to see this the very night before the
intended wedding, for in the mean time, I will so fashion the
matter, that Hero shall be absent and there shall appear such seeming
truth of Heroes disloyalty, that jealousy shall be called
assurance, and all the preparation overthrown.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
Grow this to what adverse issue it can, I will put it in
practise: be cunning in the working this, and thy fee is a
thousand ducats.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Be you constant in the accusation, and my cunning
shall not shame me.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: I will presently go learn their day of marriage.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Signior.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
In my chamber window lies a book, bring it hither
to me in the orchard.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I am here already sir.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I know that, but I would have thee hence and here
again. I do much wonder, that one man seeing how much another
man is a fool, when he dedicates his behaviours to love,
will after he hath laughed at such shallow follies in others, become
the argument of his own scorn, by falling in love, and such a
man is Claudio, I have known when there was no music
with him but the drum and the fife, and now had he rather
hear the tabor and the pipe: I have known when he would
have walked ten mile afoot, to see a good armour, and now will
he lie ten nights awake carving the fashion of a new doublet: he
was wont to speak plain, and to the purpose (like an honest
man and a soldier) and now is he turned orthography, his words
are a very fantastical banquet, just so many strange dishes:
may I be so converted and see with these eyes? I cannot tell, I
think not: I will not be sworn but love may transform me to
an oyster, but I will take my oath on it, till he have made and
oyster of me, he shall never make me such a fool: one woman is
fair, yet I am well, another is wise, yet I am well: another
virtuous, yet I am well: but till all graces be in one woman, one
woman shall not come in my grace: rich she shall be that is certain,
wise, or I will none, virtuous, or I will never cheapen her: fair, or I will
never look on her, mild, or come not near me, noble, or not I
for an angel, of good discourse, an excellent musician, and her
hair shall be of what colour it please God. ha! the prince and
monsieur Love I will hide me in the arbor.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Come shall we hear this music?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Yea my good lord: how still the evening is,
As hushed on purpose to grace harmony!

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: See you where Benedicke hath hid himself

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: O very well my lord: the music ended,
We will fit the kid-fox with a penny worth.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Come Balthaser, we will that song again.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.l: O good my lord, tax not so bad a voice,
To slander music any more than once.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: It is the witness still of excellency,
To put a strange face on his own perfection,
I pray thee sing, and let me woo no more.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.l: Because you talk of wooing I will sing,
Since many a wooer doth commence his suit,
To her he thinks not worthy, yet he woos,
Yet will he swear he loves.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Nay pray thee come,
Or if thou wilt hold longer argument,
Do it in notes.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.l: Note this before my notes,
There is not a note of mine that is worth the noting.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Why these are very crotchets that he speaks,
Note notes forsooth, and nothing.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Now divine air, now is his soul ravished, is it not
strange that sheeps guts should hale souls out of men's
bodies? well a horn for my money when all is done.

sp.l: Sigh no more ladies, sigh no more,
Men were deceivers ever,
One foot in sea, and one on shore,
To one thing constant never,
Then sigh not so, but let them go,
And be you blithe and bonnie,
Converting all your sounds of woe,
Into hey nonny nonny.
Sing no more ditties, sing no more,
Of dumps so dull and heavy,
The fraud of men was ever so,
Since summer first was leafy,
Then sigh not so, etcetera

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: By my troth a good song.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.l: And an ill singer my lord.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Ha, no no faith, thou singest well enough for a shift.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
And he had been a dog that should have howled thus,
they would have hanged him, and I pray God his bad voice
bode no mischief, I had as lief have heard the night-raven,
come what plague could have come after it.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Yea marry, dost thou hear Balthasar? I pray thee
get us some excellent music: for tomorrow night we would
have it at the lady Heroes chamber window.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: The best I can my lord.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Do so, farewell. Come hither Leonato, what was
it you told me of today,
that your niece Beatrice was in love
with signior Benedicke?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
O Aye stalk on, stalk on, the fowl sits. I did never think
that lady would have loved any man.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
No nor I neither, but most wonderful, that she should
so dote on signior Benedicke, whom she hath in all outward
behaviours seemed ever to abhor.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Is it possible? sits the wind in that corner?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
By my troth my Lord, I cannot tell what to think of
it, but that she loves him with an enraged affection, it is past the
infinite of thought.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: May be she doth but counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Faith like enough.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
O God! counterfeit? there was never counterfeit of
passion, came so near the life of passion as she discovers it.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Why what effects of passion shows she?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Bait the hook well, this fish will bite.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
What effects my Lord? she will sit you, you heard my
daughter tell you how.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: She did indeed.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
How, how I pray you! you amaze me, I would have
thought her spirit had been invincible against all assaults of
affection.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
I would have sworn it had, my lord, especially against
Benedicke.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I should think this a gull, but that the white bearded
fellow speaks it: knavery cannot sure hide himself in such reverence.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: He hath taken the infection hold it up.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Hath she made her affection known to Benedicke?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: No, and swears she never will that is her torment.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p:
It is true indeed, so your daughter says: shall I, says
she, that have so oft encountered him with scorn, write to him
that I love him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
This says she now when she is beginning to write to
him, for she will be up twenty times a night, and there will she sit
in her smock, till she have writ a sheet of paper: my daughter
tells us all.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a pretty
jest your daughter told of us.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
O when she had writ it, and was reading it over, she
found Benedicke and Beatrice between the sheet.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: That.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
O she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence, railed
at herself, that she should be so immodest to write, to one that
she knew would flout her, I measure him, says she, by my own
spirit, for I should flout him, if he writ to me, yea though I love
him I should.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
Then down upon her knees she falls, weeps, sobs,
beats her heart, tears her hair, prays, curses, O sweet Benedicke,
God give me patience.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
She doth indeed, my daughter says so, and the ecstasy
hath so much overborne her that daughter is sometime
afeared she will do desperate out-rage to herself, it is
very true.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
It were good that Benedicke knew of it by some other,
if she will not discover it.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p:
To what end? he would make but a sport of it, and
torment the poor Lady worse.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
If he should, it were an alms to hang him, she is
an excellent sweet lady, and (out of all suspicion,) she is virtuous.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: And she is exceeding wise.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: In everything but in loving Benedicke.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
O my Lord, wisdom and blood combating in
so tender a body, we have ten proofs to one, that blood hath
the victory, I am sorry for her, as I have just cause, being her
uncle, and her guardian.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
I would she had bestowed this dotage on me, I
would have daft all other respects, and made her half myself:
I pray you tell Benedicke of it, and hear what he will say.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: Were it good think you?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p:
Hero thinks surely she will die, for she says she
will die, if he love her not, and she will die ere she make her
love known, and she will die if he woo her, rather than she
will bate one breath of her accustomed crossness.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
She doth well, if she should make tender of her
love, it is very possible he will scorn it, for the man (as you know
all) hath a contemptible spirit.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: He is a very proper man.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: He hath indeed a good outward happiness.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: Before God, and in my mind, very wise.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
He doth indeed show some sparks that are like
wit.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: And I take him to be valiant.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
As Hector, I assure you, and in the managing of
quarrels you may say he is wise, for either he avoids them
with great discretion, or undertakes them with a most Christian-like
fear.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
If he do fear God, he must necessarily keep peace,
if he break the peace, he ought to enter into a quarrel with
fear and trembling.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
And so will he do, for the man doth fear God,
howsoever it seems not in him, by some large jests he will
make: well I am sorry for your niece, shall we go seek Benedicke,
and tell him of her love?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p:
never tell him, my Lord, let her wear it out with
good counsel.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
Nay that is impossible, she may wear her heart
out first.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Well, we will hear further of it by your daughter,
let it cool the while, I love Benedicke well, and I could wish
he would modestly examine himself, to see how much he is
unworthy so good a lady.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: My lord, will you walk? dinner is ready.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p:
If he do not dote on her upon this, I will never
trust my expectation.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Let there be the same net spread for her, and that
must your daughter and her gentlewomen carry: the sport
will be, when they hold one an opinion of anothers dotage,
and no such matter, that is the scene that I woulde see, which
will be merely a dumb show: let us send her to call him in to
dinner.

sp.speaker: Benedicke
sp.p:
This can be no trick, the conference was sadly
borne, they have the truth of this from Hero, they seem to
pity the Lady: it seems her affections have their full bent:
love me? why it must be requited: I hear how I am censured,
they say I will bear myself proudly, if I perceive the love
come from her: they say too, that she will rather die than give
any sign of affection: I did never think to marry, I must
not seem proud, happy are they that hear their detractions,
and can put them to mending: they say the Lady is fair, it is a
truth, I can bear them witness: and virtuous, it is so, I cannot
reprove it, and wise, but for loving me, by my troth it is
no addition to her wit, nor no great argument of her folly, for
I will be horribly in love with her, I may chance have some
odd quirks and remnants of wit broken on me, because I
have railed so long against marriage: but doth not the appetite
alter? a man loves the meat in his youth, that he cannot endure
in his age. Shall quips and sentences, and these paper
bullets of the brain awe a man from the carrier of his humour?
No, the world must be peopled. When I said I would die a
bachelor, I did not think I should live till I were married, here
comes Beatrice: by this day, she is a fair lady, I do spy some
marks of love in her.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p: Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to dinner.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I took no more pains for those thanks, than you
take pains to thank me, if it had been painful I would not have
come.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: You take pleasure then in the message.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Yea just so much as you may take upon a knives
point, and choke a daw withal: you have no stomach signior,
fare you well.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Ha, against my will I am sent to bid you come in to
dinner: there is a double meaning in that: I took no more pains
for those thanks than you took pains to thank me, that is as much
as to say, any pains that I take for you is as easy as thanks: if I do
not take pity of her I am a villain, if I do not love her I am a
Jew, I will go get her picture,

div2.stage: Enter Hero and two Gentlewomen, Margaret, and Vrsley.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: Good Margaret run thee to the parlour,
There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice,
Proposing with the prince and Claudio,
Whisper her ear and tell her I and Vrsley,
Walk in the orchard, and our whole discourse
Is all of her, say that thou over-heardest us,
And bid her steal into the pleached bower
Where honeysuckles ripened by the sun,
Forbid the sun to enter: like favourites,
Made proud by princes, that advance their pride,
Against that power that bred it, there will she hide her,
To listen our propose, this is thy office,
Bear thee well in it, and leave us alone.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I will make her come I warrant you presently.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: Now Vrsula, when Beatrice doth come,
As we do trace this alley up and down,
Our talk must only be of Benedicke,
When I do name him let it be thy part,
To praise him more than ever man did merit,
My talk to thee must be how Benedicke,
Is sick in love with Beatrice: of this matter,
Is little Cupids crafty arrow made,
That only wounds by hear-say: now begin,
For look where Beatrice like a Lapwing runs
Close by the ground, to hear our conference.

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.l: The pleasantest angling is to see the fish
Cut with her golden ores the silver stream,
And greedily devour the treacherous bait:
So angle we for Beatrice, who even now,
Is couched in the woodbine coverture,
Fear you not my part of the dialogue.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: Then go we near her that her ear lose nothing,
Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it:
No truly Vrsula, she is too disdainful,
I know her spirits are as coy and wild,
As haggards of the rock.

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.l: But are you sure,
That Benedicke loves Beatrice so entirely?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: So says the prince, and my new trothed Lord.

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.l: And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: They did entreat me to acquaint her of it,
But I persuaded them, if they loved Benedicke,
To wish him wrestle with affection,
And never to let Beatrice know of it.

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.l: Why did you so, doth not the gentleman
Deserve as full as fortunate a bed,
As ever Beatrice shall couch upon

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: O God of love! I know he doth deserve,
As much as may be yielded to a man:
But nature never framed a woman's heart,
Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice:
Disdain and Scorn ride sparkling in her eyes,
Misprising what they look on, and her wit
Values itself so highly, that to her
All matter else seems weak: she cannot love,
Nor take no shape nor project of affection,
She is so self endeared.

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.l: Sure I think so,
And therefore certainly it were not good,
She knew his love lest she will make sport at it.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: Why you speak truth, I never yet saw man,
How wise, how noble, young, how rarely featured.
But she would spell him backward: if fair faced,
She would swear the gentleman should be her sister:
If black, why Nature drawing of an antique,
Made a foul blot: if tall, a lance ill headed:
If low, an agot very vildly cut:
If speaking, why a vane blown with all winds:
If silent, why a block moved with none:
So turns she every man the wrong side out,
And never gives to Truth and Virtue, that
Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.l: Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: No not to be so odd, and from all fashions,
As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable,
But who dare tell her so? if I should speak,
She would mock me into air, O she would laugh me
Out of myself press me to death with wit,
Therefore let Benedicke like covered fire,
Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly:
It were a better death, than die with mocks,
Which is as bad as die with tickling.

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.l: Yet tell her of it, hear what she will say.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: No rather I will go to Benedicke,
And counsel him to fight against his passion,
And truly I will devise some honest slanders,
To stain my cousin with, one doth not know,
How much an ill word may empoison liking.

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.l: O do not do your cousin such a wrong,
She cannot be so much without true judgment,
Having so swift and excellent a wit,
As she is prized to have, as to refuse
So rare a gentleman as signior Benedicke.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: He is the only man of Italy,
Always excepted my dear Claudio

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.l: I pray you be not angry with me, madam,
Speaking my fancy: signior Benedicke,
For shape, for bearing argument and valour,
Goes foremost in report through Italy.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: Indeed he hath an excellent good name.

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.l: His excellence did earn it, ere he had it:
When are you married madam?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: Why every day tomorrow, come go in,
I will show thee some attires, and have thy counsel,
Which is the best to furnish me tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.l: She is limed I warrant you,
We have caught her madam.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: If it prove so, then loving goes by haps,
Some Cupid kills with arrows, some with traps.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: What fire is in mine ears? can this be true?
Stand I condemned for pride and scorn so much?
Contempt, farewell, and maiden pride, adieu,
No glory lives behind the back of such.
And Benedicke, love on I will requite thee,
Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand:
If thou dost love, my kindness shall incite thee
To bind our loves up in a holy band.
For others say thou dost deserve, and I
Believe it better than reporting.

div2.stage: Enter Prince, Claudio, Benedicke, and Leonato.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and
then go I toward Arragon.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
I will bring you thither my lord, if you will vouchsafe
me.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Nay that would be as great a soil in the new gloss
of your marriage, as to show a child his new coat and forbid
him to wear it, I will only be bold with Benedick for his company,
for from the crown of his head, to the sole of his foot,
he is all mirth, he hath twice or thrice cut Cupids bow-string,
and the little hang-man dare not shoot at him, he hath a heart
as sound as a bell, and his tongue is the clapper, for what his
heart thinks, his tongue speaks.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Gallants, I am not as I have been.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: So say I, methinks you are sadder.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: I hope he be in love.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Hang him truant, there is no true drop of blood in
him to be truly touched with love, if he be sad, he wants money.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: I have the tooth-ache.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Draw it.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Hang it.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: You must hang it first, and draw it afterwards.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: What? sigh for the tooth-ache.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Where is but a humour or a worm.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Well, every one cannot master a grief, but he that
has it.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Yet say I, he is in love.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
There is no appearance of fancy in him, unless it
be a fancy that he hath to strange disguises, as to be a Dutchman
today, a French-man tomorrow, or in the shape of two
countries at once, as a Germaine from the waste downward,
all slops, and a Spaniard from the hip upward, no doublet: unless
he have a fancy to this foolery, as it appears he hath,
he is no fool for fancy, as you would have it appear he
is.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
If he be not in love with some woman, there is no believing
old signs, he brushes his hat a mornings, what should
that bode?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Hath any man seen him at the Barbers?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
No, but the barbers man hath been seen with him,
and the old ornament of his cheek hath already stuffed tennis
balls.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Indeed he looks younger than he did, by the loss of
a beard.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Nay he rubs himself with civet, can you smell him
out by that?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
That is as much as to say, the sweet youth is in
love.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: The greatest note of it is his melancholy.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: And when was he wont to wash his face?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Yea or to paint himself? for the which I hear what
they say of him.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Nay but his jesting spirit, which is now crept into a
lute-string, and now governed by stops.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Indeed that tells a heavy tale for him: conclude, conclude,
he is in loue.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Nay but I know who loves him.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
That would I know too, I warrant one that knows
him not.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Yes, and his ill conditions, and in despite of all, dies
for him.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: She shall be buried with her face upwards.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Yet is this no charm for the tooth-ache, old signior,
walk aside with me, I have studied eight or nine wise words
to speak to you, which these hobby-horses must not hear.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: For my life to break with him about Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
It is even so, Hero and Margaret have by this played
their parts with Beatrice, and then the two bears will not
bite one another when they meet.

sp.speaker: Bastard
sp.p: My lord and brother, God save you.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Good den brother.

sp.speaker: Bastard
sp.p: If your leisure served, I would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: In private?

sp.speaker: Bastard
sp.p:
If it please you, yet Count Claudio may hear, for
what I would speak of, concerns him.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: Means your Lordship to be married tomorrow?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: You know he does.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: I know not that, when he knows what I know.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
You may think I love you not, let that appear hereafter,
and aim better at me by that I now will manifest, for
my brother (I think, he holds you well, and in dearness of
heart) hath helped to effect your ensuing marriage: surely suit ill
spent, and labour ill bestowed.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Why what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
I came hither to tell you, and circumstances shortened,
(for she has been too long a talking of) the lady is disloyal.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Who Hero?

sp.speaker: Bastar.
sp.p:
even she, Leonatoes Hero, your Hero, every man's
Hero.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Disloyal?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
The word is too good to paint out her wickedness, I
could say she were worse, think you of a worse title, and I will
fit her to it: wonder not till further warrant: go but with me
tonight you shall see her chamber window entered, even the
night before her wedding day, if you love her, then tomorrow
wed her: But it would better fit your honour to change your
mind.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: May this be so?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: I will not think it.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
If you dare not trust that you see, confess not that
you know: if you will follow me, I will show you enough,
and when you have seen more, and heard more, proceed
accordingly.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p:
If I see anything tonight, why I should not marry
her tomorrow in the congregation, where I should wed,
there will I shame her.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
And as I wooed for thee to obtain her, I will join
with thee, to disgrace her.

sp.speaker: Bastard
sp.p:
I will disparage her no farther, till you are my witnesses,
bear it coldly but till midnight, and let the issue show
itself.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: O day untowardly turned!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: O mischief strangely thwarting!

sp.speaker: Bastard
sp.p:
O plague right well prevented! so will you say,
when you have seen the sequel.

div2.stage: Enter Dogbery and his compartner with the Watch. some of Q's speech prefixes re the watchmen in this scene are confusing

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Are you good men and true?

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.p:
Yea, or else it were pity but they should suffer
salvation body and soul.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Nay, that were a punishment too good for them, if
they should have any allegiance in them, being chosen for the
Princes watch.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.p: Well, give them their charge, neighbour Dogbery.

sp.speaker: Dogbery
sp.p:
First, who think you the most desertless man
to be Constable?

sp.speaker: Watch 1
sp.p:
Hugh Ote-cake sir, or George Sea-cole, for they
can write and read.

sp.speaker: Dogbery
sp.p:
Come hither neighbour Sea-cole, God hath blessed
you with a good name: to be a well-favoured man, is the gift of
Fortune, but to write and read, comes by nature.

sp.speaker: Watch 2
sp.p: Both which master Constable.

sp.speaker: Dogbery
sp.p:
You have: I knew it would be your answer: well,
for your favour sir, why give God thanks, and make no boast
of it, and for your writing and reading, let that appear when
there is no need of such vanity, you are thought here to be
the most senseless and fit man for the Constable of the watch:
therefore bear you the lantern: this is your charge, You
shall comprehend all vagrant men, you are to bid any man
stand, in the Princes name.

sp.speaker: Watch 2
sp.p: How if he will not stand?

sp.speaker: Dogbery
sp.p:
Why then take no note of him, but let him go,
and presently call the rest of the watch together, and thank
god you are rid of a knave.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.p:
If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none of
the Princes subjects.

sp.speaker: Dogbery
sp.p:
True, and they are to meddle with none but the
Princes subjects: you shall also make no noise in the streets:
for, for the watch to babble and to talk, is most tolerable, and
not to be endured.

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.p:
We will rather sleep than talk, we know what
belongs to a watch.

sp.speaker: Dogbery
sp.p:
Why you speak like an ancient and most quiet
watchman, for I cannot see how sleeping should offend: only
have a care that your bills be not stolen: well, you are to
call at all the alehouses, and bid those that are drunk get them to
bed.

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.p: How if they will not?

sp.speaker: Dogbery
sp.p:
Why then let them alone till they are sober, if they
make you not then the better answer, you may say, they are not
the men you took them for.

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.p: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Dogbery
sp.p:
If you meet a thief, you may suspect him, by
virtue of your office, to be no true man: and for such kind of
men, the less you meddle or make with them, why the more
is for your honesty.

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.p:
If we know him to be a thief, shall we not lay hands
on him?

sp.speaker: Dogbery
sp.p:
Truly by your office you may, but I think they
that touch pitch will be defiled: the most peaceable way for
you, if you do take a thief, is, to let him show himself what
he is, and steal out of your company.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.p:
You have been always called a merciful man,
partner.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Truly I would not hang a dog by my will, much
more a man who hath any honesty in him.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.p:
If you hear a child cry in the night you must call to
the nurse and bid her still it.

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.p: How if the nurse be asleep and will not hear us

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Why then depart in peace, and let the child wake her
with crying, for the ewe that will not hear her lamb when it
bays, will never answer a calf when he bleats.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.p: It is very true.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
This is the end of the charge: you constable are to
present the princes own person, if you meet the prince in the
night, you may stay him.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.p: Nay by Our Lady that I think he cannot.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Five shillings to one on it with any man that knows
the statutes, he may stay him, marry not without the prince be
willing, for indeed the watch ought to offend no man, and it is
an offence to stay a man against his will.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.p: By Our Lady I think it be so.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Ha ah ha, well masters good night, if there be any
matter of weight chances, call up me, keep your fellows
counsels, and your own, and good night, come neighbour.

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.p:
Well masters, we hear our charge, let us go sit
here upon the church bench till two, and then all to
bed.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
One word more, honest neighbours, I pray you watch
about signior Leonatoes door, for the wedding being there
tomorrow, there is a great coil tonight, adieu, be vigilant I
beseech you.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: What Conrade?

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.p: Peace, stir not.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Conrade I say.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Here man, I am at thy elbow.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Mass and my elbow itched, I thought there would a
scab follow.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
I will owe thee an answer for that, and now forward
with thy tale.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Stand thee close then under this penthouse, for it
drizzles rain, and I will, like a true drunkard, utter all to
thee.

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.p: Some treason masters, yet stand close.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Therefore know, I have earned of Dun Iohn a thousand
ducats.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Is it possible that any villainy should be so dear?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Thou shouldest rather ask if it were possible any villainy
should be so rich? for when rich villains have need of poor
ones, poor ones may make what price they will.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I wonder at it.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
That shows thou art unconfirmed, thou knowest
that the fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloak, is nothing to a
man.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Yes it is apparel.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: I mean the fashion.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Yes the fashion is the fashion.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Tush, I may as well say the fool is the fool, but seest
thou not what a deformed thief this fashion is?

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.p:
I know that deformed, he has been a vile thief, this
seven year, he goes up and down like a gentle man: I remember
his name.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Didst thou not hear somebody?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: No, it was the vane on the house.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Seest thou not (I say) what a deformed thief this fashion
is, how giddily he turns about all the Hot-bloods, between
fourteen and five and thirty, sometimes fashioning them
like Pharaoh's soldiers in the reechy painting, sometime like
god Bels priests in the old church window, sometime like the
shaven Hercules in the smirched worm-eaten tapestry, where
his codpiece seems as massy as his club.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
All this I see, and I see that the fashion wears out more
apparel than the man, but art not thou thyself giddy with
the fashion too, that thou hast shifted out of thy tale into telling
me of the fashion?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Not so neither, but know that I have tonight wooed
Margaret the Lady Heroes gentle-woman, by the name of
Hero, she leans me out at her mistress chamber window, bids
me a thousand times good night: I tell this tale vildly. I should
first tell thee how the prince Claudio and my master planted,
and placed, and possessed, by my master Don Iohn, saw a far
off in the orchard this amiable encounter.

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.p: And thought they Margaret was Hero?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Two of them did, the prince and Claudio, but the devil
my master knew she was Margaret, and partly by his oaths,
which first possessed them, partly by the dark night which did
deceive them, but chiefly, by my villainy, which did confirm
any slander that Don Iohn had made, away went Claudio
enraged, swore he would meet her as he was appointed next
morning at the Temple, and there, before the whole congregation
shame her, with what he saw over night, and send her home
again without a husband.

sp.speaker: Watch 1
sp.p: We charge you in the princes name stand.

sp.speaker: Watch 2
sp.p:
Call up the right master Constable, we have
here recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery, that ever
was known in the common wealth.

sp.speaker: Watch 1
sp.p:
And one Deformed is one of them, I know him, he
wears a lock.

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.p: Masters, masters.

sp.speaker: Watch 2
sp.p:
You will be made bring deformed forth I warrant
you.

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.p:
Masters, never speak, we charge you, let us obey you
to go with us.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
We are like to prove a goodly commodity, being taken
up of these men's bills.

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.p:
A commodity in question I warrant you, come we will
obey you.

div2.stage: Enter Hero, and Margaret, and Vrsula.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p:
Good Vrsula wake my cousin Beatrice, and desire her
to rise.

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.p: I will lady.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p: And bid her come hither.

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Troth I think your other rebate were better.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p: No pray thee good Meg, I will wear this.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
By my troth is not so good, and I warrant your cousin
will say so.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p:
My cousin is a fool, and thou art another, I will wear
none but this.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I like the new tire within excellently, if the hair were a
thought browner: and your gown is a most rare fashion in faith
I saw the Duchess of Millaines gown that they praise so.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p: O that exceeds they say.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
By my troth is but a night-gown it respect of yours,
cloth a gold and cuts, and laced with silver, set with pearls,
down sleeves, side sleeves, and skirts, round underborne with
a bluish tinsel, but for a fine quaint graceful and excellent
fashion, yours is worth ten of it

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p:
God give me joy to wear it, for my heart is exceeding
heavy.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
It will be heavier soon by the weight of a
man.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p: Fie upon thee, art not ashamed?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
Of what lady? of speaking honourably? is not marriage
honourable in a beggar? is not your Lord honourable
without marriage? I think you would have me say, saving your
reverence a husband: and bad thinking do not wrest true speaking,
I will offend nobody, is there any harm in the heavier, for a
husband? none I think, if it be the right husband, and the
right wife, otherwise it is light and not heavy, ask my lady Beatrice
else, here she comes.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p: Good morrow cuz.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Good morrow sweet Hero.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p: Why how now? do you speak in the sick tune?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I am out of all other tune, methinks

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Clap us into Light a love, (that goes without a burden,)
do you sing it. and I will dance it.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Ye Light alove with your heels, then if your husband
have stables enough you will see he shall lack no barnes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
O illegitimate construction! I scorn that with my
heels.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
It is almost five a clock cousin, it is time you were ready,
by my troth I am exceeding ill, hey ho.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: For a hawk, a horse, or a husband?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: For the letter that begins them all, H.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Well, if you be not turned Turke, there is no more
sailing by the star.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What means the fool trow?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nothing I, but God send every one their hearts desire.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p:
These gloves the Count sent me, they are an excellent
perfume.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I am stuffed cousin, I cannot smell.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
A maid and stuffed! there is goodly catching of
cold.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
O God help me, God help me, how long have you
professed apprehension?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
ever since you left it, doth not my wit become me
rarely?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
It is not seen enough, you should wear it in your
cap, by my troth I am sick.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Get you some of this distilled carduus benedictus,
and lay it to your heart, it is the only thing for a qualm.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p: There thou prickest her with a thistle.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Benedictus, why benedictus? you have some moral in this
benedictus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Moral? no by my troth I have no moral meaning,
I meant plain holy thistle, you may think perchance that I
think you are in love, nay by Our Lady I am not such a fool to think
what I list, nor I list not to think what I can, nor indeed I can
not think, if I would think my heart out of thinking, that you
are in love, or that you will be in love, or that you can be in
love: yet Benedicke was such another, and now is he become a
man, he swore he would never marry, and yet now in despite
of his heart he eats his meat without grudging, and how you
may be converted I know not, but methinks you look with
your eyes as other women do.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What pace is this that thy tongue keeps?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Not a false gallop.

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.p:
Madam withdraw, the prince, the Count, signior
Benedicke, Don Iohn, and all the gallants of the town are
come to fetch you to church.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p: Help to dress me good cuz, good Meg, good Vrsula.

div2.stage: Enter Leonato, and the Constable, and the Headborough.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: What would you with me, honest neighbour?

sp.speaker: Const.Dog.
