sp.p:
Marry sir I would have some confidence with
you, that discerns you nearly.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
Brief I pray you, for you see it is a busy time with
me.

sp.speaker: Const.Dog.
sp.p: Marry this it is sir.

sp.speaker: Headb.
sp.p: Yes in truth it is sir.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: What is it my good friends?

sp.speaker: Con.Do.
sp.p:
Goodman Verges sir speaks a little of the matter,
an old man sir, and his wits are not so blunt, as God help I
would desire they were, but in faith honest, as the skin between
his brows.

sp.speaker: Head.
sp.p:
Yes I thank God, I am as honest as any man living,
that is an old man, and no honester than I.

sp.speaker: Const.Dog.
sp.p:
Comparisons are odorous, palabras, neighbour
Verges.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: Neighbours, you are tedious.

sp.speaker: Const.Dog.
sp.p:
It pleases your worship to say so, but we are the
poor Dukes officers, but truly for mine own part, if I were as
tedious as a King I could find in my heart to bestow it all of
your worship.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: All thy tediousness on me, ah?

sp.speaker: Const.Dog.
sp.p:
Yea, if it were a thousand pound more than it is,
for I hear as good exclamation on your worship as of any
man in the city, and though I be but a poor man, I am glad to
hear it.

sp.speaker: Head.
sp.p: And so am I.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: I would fain know what you have to say.

sp.speaker: Head.
sp.p:
Marry sir our watch tonight, excepting your worships
presence, has taken a couple of as arrant knaves as any in
Messina.

sp.speaker: Const.Dog.
sp.p:
A good old man sir, he will be talking as they
say, when the age is in, the wit is out, God help us it is a world
to see: well said in faith neighbour Verges, well, god is a good
man, and two men ride of a horse, one must ride behind, an honest
soul in faith sir, by my troth he is, as ever broke bread, but
God is to be worshipped, all men are not alike, alas good neighbour.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: Indeed neighbour he comes too short of you.

sp.speaker: Const.Do.
sp.p: Gifts that God gives.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Const.Dog.
sp.p:
One word sir, our watch sir have indeed
comprehended two suspitious persons, and we would have them
this morning examined before your worship.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
Take their examination yourself, and bring it me,
I am now in great haste, as it may appear unto you.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: It shall be suffisance.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: Drink some wine ere you go: fare you well.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p:
My lord, they stay for you, to give your daughter
to her husband.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I will wait upon them, I am ready.

sp.speaker: Dogb.
sp.p:
Go good partner, go get you to Francis Sea-cole,
bid him bring his pen and inkhorn to the Gaol: we are
now to examination these men.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.p: And we must do it wisely.

sp.speaker: Dogbery
sp.p:
We will spare for no wit I warrant you: here is
that shall drive some of them to a noncome, only get the learned
writer to set down our excommunication, and meet me
at the Jail.

div2.stage:
Enter Prince, Bastard, Leonato, Frier, Claudio, Bene-
dicke, Hero, and Beatrice

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
Come Frier Francis, be brief, only to the plain
form of marriage, and you shall recount their particular
duties afterwards.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You come hither, my lord, to marry this lady.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: To be married to her: Frier, you come to marry her.

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.p: Lady, you come hither to be married to this count.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.p:
If either of you know any inward impediment why
you should not be conjoined, I charge you on your souls to
utter it.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: Know you any, Hero?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.p: None my lord.

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.p: Know you any, Count?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: I dare make his answer, None.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
O what men dare do! what men may do! what men
daily do, not knowing what they do!

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
How now! interjections? why then, some be of
laughing, as, ah, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Stand thee by Frier, father by your leave,
Will you with free and unconstrained soul
Give me this maid your daughter?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: As freely son as God did give her me.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p:
And what have I to give you back whose worth
May counterpoise this rich and precious gift?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Nothing, unless you render her again.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Sweet Prince, you learn me noble thankfulness:
There Leonato, take her back again,
Give not this rotten orange to your friend,
She is but the sign and semblance of her honour:
Behold how like a maid she blushes here!
O what authority and show of truth
Can cunning sin cover itself withal!
Comes not that blood, as modest evidence,
To witness simple Virtue? would you not swear
All you that see her, that she were a maid,
By these exterior shows? But she is none:
She knows the heat of a luxurious bed:
Her blush is guiltiness, not modesty.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: What do you mean my lord?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Not to be married,
Not to knit my soul to an approved wanton.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Dear my lord, if you in your own proof,
Have vanquished the resistance of her youth,
And made defeat of her virginity.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: I know what you would say: if I have known her,
You will say, she did embrace me as a husband,
And so extenuate the forehand sin: No Leonato,
I never tempted her with word too large,
But as a brother to his sister, showed
Bashful sincerity, and comely love.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: And seemed I ever otherwise to you?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Out on thee seeming. I will write against it,
You seem to me as Diane in her Orb,
As chaste as is the bud ere it be blown:
But you are more intemperate in your blood,
Than Venus, or those pampered animals,
That rage in savage sensuality.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: Is my Lord well that he doth speak so wide?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Sweet prince, why speak not you?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: What should I speak?
I stand dishonoured that have gone about,
To link my dear friend to a common stale.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Are these things spoken, or do I but dream?

sp.speaker: Bastard
sp.l: Sir, they are spoken, and these things are true.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.l: This looks not like a nuptial.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: True, O God!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Leonato, stand I here?
Is this the prince? is this the princes brother?
Is this face Heroes? are our eyes our own?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: All this is so, but what of this my Lord?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Let me but move one question to your daughter,
And by that fatherly and kindly power,
That you have in her, bid her answer truly.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: I charge thee do so, as thou art my child.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: O God defend me how am I beset,
What kind of catechising call you this?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: To make you answer truly to your name.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: Is it not Hero, who can blot that name
With any just reproach?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Marry that can Hero,
Hero itself can blot out Heroes virtue.
What man was he talked with you yesternight,
Out at your window betwixt twelve and one?
Now if you are a maid, answer to this.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: I talked with no man at that hour my lord.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Why then are you no maiden. Leonato,
I am sorry you must hear: upon mine honour,
Myself, my brother, and this grieved Count
Did see her, hear her, at that hour last night,
Talk with a ruffian at her chamber window,
Who hath indeed most like a liberal villain,
Confessed the vile encounters they have had
A thousand times in secret.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Fie, fie, they are not to be named my lord,
Not to be spoke of,
There is not chastity enough in language,
Without offence to utter them: thus pretty lady,
I am sorry for thy much misgovernment.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: O Hero! what a Hero hadst thou been,
If half thy outward graces had been placed,
About thy thoughts and counsels of thy heart?
But fare thee well, most foul, most fair, farewell
Thou pure impiety, and impious purity,
For thee I will lock up all the gates of Love,
And on my eyelids shall Conjecture hang,
To turn all beauty into thoughts of harm,
And never shall it more be gracious.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Hath no man's dagger here a point for me.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.l: Why how now cousin, wherefore sink you down?

sp.speaker: Bastard
sp.l: Come let us go: these things come thus to light,
Smother her spirits up

sp.speaker: Benedicke
sp.l: How doth the Lady?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.l: Dead I think, help uncle,
Hero, why Hero, uncle, signior Benedicke, Frier.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: O Fate! take not away thy heavy hand,
Death is the fairest cover for her shame
That may be wished for.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.l: How now cousin Hero?

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.l: Have comfort lady.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Dost thou look up

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.l: Yea, wherefore should she not?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Wherefore? why doth not every earthly thing,
Cry shame upon her? could she here deny
The story that is printed in her blood?
Do not live Hero, do not ope thine eyes:
For did I think thou wouldst not quickly die,
Thought I thy spirits were stronger than thy shames,
Myself would on the rearward of reproaches
Strike at thy life. Grieved I I had but one?
Chid I for that at frugal Natures frame?
O one too much by thee: why had I one?
Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes?
Why had I not with charitable hand,
Took up a beggars issue at my gates,
Who smirched thus, and mired with infamy,
I might have said, no part of it is mine,
This shame derives itself from unknown loins,
But mine and mine I loved, and mine I praised,
And mine that I was proud on mine so much,
That I myself, was to myself not mine:
Valuing of her, why she, O she is fallen,
Into a pit of ink, that the wide sea
Hath drops too few to wash her clean again,
And salt too little, which may season give
To her foul tainted flesh.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Sir, sir, be patient, for my part I am so attired in wonder,
I know not what to say.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: O on my soul my cousin is belied.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Lady, were you her bedfellow last night?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: No truly, not although until last night,
I have this twelve-month been her bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Confirmed, confirmed, O that is stronger made,
Which was before bard up with ribs of iron,
Would the two princes lie, and Claudio lie,
Who loved her so, that speaking of her foulness,
Washed it with tears! hence from her, let her die.

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.p:
Hear me a little, for I have only been silent so long, and
given way unto this course of fortune, by noting of the lady, I
have marked,
sp.l: A thousand blushing apparitions,
To start into her face, a thousand innocent shames,
In angel whiteness beat away those blushes,
And in her eye there hath appeared a fire,
To burn the errors that these princes hold
Against her maiden truth: call me a fool,
Trust not my reading, nor my observations,
Which with experimental seal doth warrant
The tenure of my book: trust not my age,
My reverence, calling, nor divinity,
If this sweet lady lie not guiltless here,
Under some biting error.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Frier, it cannot be,
Thou seest that all the grace that she hath left,
Is, that she will not add to her damnation,
A sin of perjury, she not denies it:
Why seekst thou then to cover with excuse,
That which appears in proper nakedness?

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.l: Lady, what man is he you are accused of?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: They know that do accuse me, I know none,
If I know more of any man alive
Then that which maiden modesty doth warrant,
Let all my sins lack mercy, O my father,
Prove you that any man with me conversed,
At hours unmeet, or that I yesternight
Maintained the change of words with any creature,
Refuse me, hate me, torture me to death.

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.l: There is some strange misprision in the princes.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Two of them have the very bent of honour,
And if their wisdoms be misled in this,
The practise of it lives in Iohn the Bastard,
Whose spirits toil in frame of villainies.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: I know not, if they speak but truth of her,
These hands shall tear her, if they wrong her honour,
The proudest of them shall well hear of it.
Time hath not yet so dried this blood of mine,
Nor age so eat up my invention,
Nor Fortune made such havoc of my means,
Nor my bad life reft me so much of friends,
But they shall find awaked in such a kind,
Both strength of limb, and policy of mind,
Ability in means, and choice of friends,
To quit me of them thoroughly.

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.l: Pause awhile,
And let my counsel sway you in this case,
Your daughter here the princess (left for dead,)
Let her awhile be secretly kept in,
And publish it, that she is dead indeed,
Maintain a mourning ostentation,
And on your families old monument,
Hang mournful epitaphs, and do all rites,
That appertain unto a burial.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: What shall become of this? what will this do?

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.l: Marry this well carried, shall on her behalf,
Change slander to remorse, that is some good,
But not for that dream I on this strange course,
But on this travail look for greater birth:
She dying, as it must be so maintained,
Upon the instant that she was accused,
Shall be lamented, pitied, and excused
Of every hearer: for it so falls out,
That what we have, we prize not to the worth,
Whiles we enjoy it, but being lacked and lost,
Why then we rack the value, then we find
The virtue that possession would not show us
Whiles it was ours, so will it fare with Claudio:
When he shall hear she died upon his words,
the Idea of her life shall sweetly creep,
Into his study of imagination,
And every lovely Organ of her life,
Shall come appareled in more precious habit,
More moving delicate, and full of life,
Into the eye and prospect of his soul
Then when she lived indeed: then shall he mourn,
If ever love had interest in his liver,
And wish he had not so accused her:
No, though he thought his accusation true:
Let this be so, and doubt not but success
Will fashion the event in better shape,
Than I can lay it down in likelihood.
But if all aim but this be leveled false,
The supposition of the ladies death,
Will quench the wonder of her infamy.
And if it sort not well, you may conceal her,
As best befits her wounded reputation,
In some reclusive and religious life,
Out of all eyes, tongues, minds, and injuries.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Signior Leonato, let the Frier advise you,
And though you know my inwardness and love
Is very much unto the prince and Claudio,
Yet, by mine honour, I will deal in this,
As secretly and justly as your soul
Should with your body.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Being that I flow in grief,
The smallest twine may lead me.

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.l: It is well consented, presently away,
For to strange sores, strangely they strain the cure,
Come lady, die to live, this wedding day
Perhaps is but prolonged, have patience and endure.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Lady Beatrice, have you wept all this while?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Yea, and I will weep a while longer.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: I will not desire that.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: You have no reason, I do it freely.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Surely I do believe your fair cousin is wronged.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Ah, how much might the man deserve of me that
would right her!

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Is there any way to show such friendship?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: A very even way, but no such friend.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: May a man do it?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: It is a man's office, but not yours.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I do love nothing in the world so well as you,
is not that strange?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
As strange as the thing I know not, it were as possible
for me to say, I loved nothing so well as you, but believe me
not, and yet I lie not, I confess nothing, nor I deny nothing, I
am sorry for my cousin.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: By my sword Beatrice, thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Do not swear and eat it.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
I will swear by it that you love me, and I will make
him eat it that says I love not you.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Will you not eat your word?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
With no sauce that can be devised to it, I protest I
love thee.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Why then God forgive me.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: What offence sweet Beatrice?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
You have stayed me in a happy hour, I was about
to protest I loved you.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: And do it with all thy heart.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I love you with so much of my heart, that none is left
to protest.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Come bid me do anything for thee.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Kill Claudio.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Ha, not for the wide world.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: You kill me to deny it, farewell.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Tarry sweet Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I am gone, though I am here, there is no love in you,
nay I pray you let me go.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: In faith I will go.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: We will be friends first.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
You dare easier be friends with me, than fight with
mine enemy.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Is Claudio thine enemy?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Is a not approved in the height a villain, that hath
slandered, scorned, dishonoured my kinswoman? O that I
were a man! what, bear her in hand, until they come to take
hands, and then with public accusation uncovered slander,
unmitigated rancour? O God that I were a man! I would
eat his heart in the market place.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Hear me Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Talk with a man out at a window, a proper saying.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Nay but Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Sweet Hero, she is wronged, she is slandered, she is
undone.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Beat?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Princes and Counties! surely a princely testimony, a
goodly Count, Count Comfect, a sweet Gallant surely, O
that I were a man for his sake! or that I had any friend would
be a man for my sake! But manhood is melted into curtsies,
valour into complement, and men are only turned into tongue,
and trim ones too: he is now as valiant as Hercules, that only
tells a lie, and swears it: I cannot be a man with wishing,
therefore I will die a woman with grieving.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Tarry good Beatrice, by this hand I love thee.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.p:
Use it for my love some other way than swearing
by it.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
Think you in your soul the Count Claudio hath
wronged Hero?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.p: Yea, as sure as I have a thought, or a soul.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
Enough, I am engaged, I will challenge him, I will
kiss your hand, and so I leave you: by this hand, Claudio shall
render me a dear account: as you hear of me, so think of me:
go comfort your cousin, I must say she is dead, and so farewell.

div2.stage:
Enter the Constables, Borachio, and the Towne clearke
in gownes. the speaker tags in this scene are confusing. from Norton: The sexton is presumably Francis Seacoal. Q's stage directions call him the town clerk, an office more appropriate to his function in the scene than sexton, with which however, it seems often to have been combined.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Is our whole dissembly appeared?

sp.speaker: Cowley
sp.p: O a stool and a cushion for the Sexton.

sp.speaker: Sexton
sp.p: Which be the malefactors?

sp.speaker: Andrew
sp.p: Marry that am I, and my partner.

sp.speaker: Cowley
sp.p: Nay that is certain, we have the exhibition to examine.

sp.speaker: Sexton
sp.p:
But which are the offenders? that are to be examined,
let them come before master constable.

sp.speaker: Kemp
sp.p:
Yea marry, let them come before me, what is your
name, friend?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Borachio.

sp.speaker: Ke.
sp.p: Pray write down Borachio. Yours sirrah.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I am a gentleman sir, and my name is Conrade.

sp.speaker: Ke.
sp.p:
Write down master gentleman Conrade: masters,
do you serve God?

sp.speaker: Both
sp.p: Yea sir we hope.

sp.speaker: Kem.
sp.p:
Write down, that they hope they serve God: and
write God first, for God defend but God should go before
such villains: masters, it is proved already that you are little
better than false knaves, and it will go near to be thought so
shortly, how answer you for yourselves?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Marry sir we say, we are none.

sp.speaker: Kemp
sp.p:
A marvelous witty fellow I assure you, but I will
go about with him: come you hither sirrah, a word in your ear
sir, I say to you it is thought you are false knaves.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Sir, I say to you, we are none.

sp.speaker: Kemp
sp.p:
Well stand aside, fore God they are both in a tale:
have you writ down, that they are none?

sp.speaker: Sexton
sp.p:
Master constable, you go not the way to examine,
you must call forth the watch that are their accusers.

sp.speaker: Kemp
sp.p:
Yea marry, that is the eftest way, let the watch come
forth: masters, I charge you in the Princes name accuse these
men.

sp.speaker: Watch 1
sp.p:
This man said sir, that don Iohn the Princes brother
was a villain.

sp.speaker: Kemp
sp.p:
Write down, prince Iohn a villain: why this is flat
perjury, to call a Princes brother villain.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.p: Master Constable.

sp.speaker: Kemp
sp.p:
Pray thee fellow peace, I do not like thy look I
promise thee.

sp.speaker: Sexton
sp.p: What heard you him say else?

sp.speaker: Watch 2
sp.p:
Marry that he had received a thousand ducats of
don Iohn, for accusing the Lady Hero wrongfully.

sp.speaker: Kemp
sp.p: Flat burglary as ever was committed.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yea by mass that it is.

sp.speaker: Sexton
sp.p: What else fellow?

sp.speaker: Watch 1
sp.p:
And that Count Claudio did mean upon his
words, to disgrace Hero before the whole assembly, and not
marry her.

sp.speaker: Kemp
sp.p:
O villain! thou wilt be condemned into everlasting
redemption for this.

sp.speaker: Sexton
sp.p: What else?

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.p: This is all.

sp.speaker: Sexton
sp.p:
And this is more masters than you can deny, prince
Iohn is this morning secretly stolen away: Hero was in this
manner accused, in this very manner refused, and
upon the
grief of this, suddenly died: Master Constable, let these men
be bound, and brought to Leonatoes, I will goe before and
show him their examination.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Come, let them be opinioned.

sp.speaker: Couley
sp.p: Norton emends last 2 words of this speech to "off Coxcomb" and gives them to ConradLet them be in the hands of Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Kemp
sp.p:
Gods my life, where is the Sexton? let him write down
the Princes officer Coxcomb: come, bind them, thou naughty
varlet.

sp.speaker: Couley
sp.p: Norton gives this speech to Conrad Away, you are an ass, you are an ass.

sp.speaker: Kemp
sp.p:
Dost thou not suspect my place? dost thou not
suspect my years? O that he were here to write me down an
ass! but masters, remember that I am an ass, though it be
not written down, yet forget not that I am an ass: No thou
villain, thou art full of piety as shall be proved upon thee by
good witness, I am a wise fellow, and which is more, an officer,
and which is more, a householder, and which is more, as pretty
a piece of flesh as any is in Messina, and one that knows
the Law, go to, and a rich fellow enough, go to, and a fellow
that hath had losses, and one that hath two gowns, and everything
handsome about him: bring him away: O that I had been
writ down an ass!

sp.speaker: Brother
sp.l: If you go on thus, you will kill yourself,
And it is not wisdom thus to second grief,
Against yourself.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: I pray thee cease thy counsel,
Which falls into mine ears as profitless,
As water in a sieve: give not me counsel,
Nor let no comforter delight mine ear,
But such a one whose wrongs do suit with mine.
Bring me a father that so loved his child,
Whose joy of her is overwhelmed like mine,
And bid him speak of patience,
Measure his woe the length and breadth of mine,
And let it answer every strain for strain,
As thus for thus, and such a grief for such,
In every lineament, branch, shape, and form:
If such a one will smile and stroke his beard,
And sorrow, wag, cry hem, when he should groan,
Patch grief with proverbs, make misfortune drunk,
With candle-wasters: bring him yet to me,
And I of him will gather patience:
But there is no such man, for brother, men
Can counsel, and speak comfort to that grief,
Which they themselves not feel, but tasting it,
Their counsel turns to passion, which before,
Would give perceptual medicine to rage,
Fetter strong madness in a silken thread,
Charm ache with air, and agony with words,
No, no, it is all men's office, to speak patience
To those that wring under the load of sorrow
But no man's virtue nor sufficiency
To be so moral, when he shall endure
The like himself: therefore give me no counsel,
My griefs cry louder than advertisement.

sp.speaker: Brother
sp.l: Therein do men from children nothing differ.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: I pray thee peace, I will be flesh and blood,
For there was never yet Philosopher,
That could endure the tooth-ache patiently,
How ever they have writ the style of gods,
And made a push at chance and sufferance.

sp.speaker: Brother
sp.l: Yet bend not all the harm upon yourself,
Make those that do offend you, suffer too.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: There thou speakest reason, nay I will do so,
My soul doth tell me, Hero is belied,
And that shall Claudio know, so shall the prince,
And all of them that thus dishonour her.

sp.speaker: Brother
sp.l: Here comes the Prince and Claudio hastily.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Good den, good den.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Good day to both of you.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Hear you my Lords?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: We have some haste Leonato.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Some haste my lord! well, fare you well my lord,
Are you so hasty now? well, all is one.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Nay do not quarrel with us, good old man.

sp.speaker: Brother
sp.l: If he could right himself with quarrelling,
Some of us would lie low.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Who wrongs him?

sp.speaker: Leona.
sp.l: Marry thou dost wrong me, thou dissembler, thou:
Nay, never lay thy hand upon thy sword,
I fear thee not.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Marry beshrew my hand,
If it should give your age such cause of fear,
In faith my hand meant nothing to my sword.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Tush, tush man, never fleer and jest at me,
I speak not like a dotard, nor a fool,
As under privilege of age to brag,
What I have done being young, or what would do,
Were I not old, know Claudio to thy head,
Thou hast so wronged mine innocent child and me,
That I am forced to lay my reverence by,
And with grey hairs and bruise of many days,
Do challenge thee to trial of a man,
I say thou hast belied mine innocent child.
Thy slander hath gone through and through her heart,
And she lies buried with her ancestors:
O in a tomb where never scandal slept,
Save this of hers, framed by thy villainy.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: My villainy?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Thine Claudio, thine I say.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: You say not right old man.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord,
I will prove it on his body if he dare,
Despite his nice fence, and his active practise,
His May of youth, and bloom of lustihood.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Away, I will not have to do with you.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Canst thou so doff me? thou hast killed my child,
If thou killest me, boy, thou shalt kill a man.

sp.speaker: Brother
sp.l: He shall kill two of us, and men indeed,
But that is no matter, let him kill one first:
Win me and wear me, let him answer me,
Come follow me boy, come sir boy, come follow me
Sir boy, I will whip you from your foining fence,
Nay, as I am a gentleman I, will.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Brother.

sp.speaker: Brother
sp.l: Content yourself, God knows, I loved my niece,
And she is dead, slandered to death by villains,
That dare as well answer a man indeed.
As I dare take a serpent by the tongue,
Boys, apes, braggarts, Iackes, milk-sops.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Brother Anthony.

sp.speaker: Brother
sp.l: Hold you content, what man! I know them, yea
And what they weigh, even to the utmost scruple,
Scambling out-facing, fashion-monging boys,
That lie, and cog, and flout, deprave, and slander,
Go antiquely, and show outward hideousness,
And speak of half a dozen dangerous words,
How they might hurt their enemies, if they durst,
And this is all.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: But brother Anthonie.

sp.speaker: Brother
sp.l: Come it is no matter,
Do not you meddle, let me deal in this.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience,
My heart is sorry for your daughters death:
But on my honour she was charged with nothing
But what was true, and very full of proof.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: I will not hear you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: No come brother, away, I will be heard.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: And shall, or some of us will smart for it.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: See see, here comes the man we went to seek.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Now signior, what news?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Good day my Lord:

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Welcome signior, you are almost come to part
almost a fray.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
We had liked to have had our two noses snapped off
with two old men without teeth.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Leonato and his brother what thinkst thou? had we
fought, I doubt we should have been too young for them.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
In a false quarrel there is no true valour, I came to
seek you both.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
We have been up and down to seek thee, for we
are high proof melancholy, and would fain have it beaten
away, wilt thou use thy wit?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: It is in my scabbard, shall I draw it?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Dost thou wear thy wit by thy side?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
never any did so, though very many have been beside
their wit, I will bid thee draw, as we do the minstrels,
draw to pleasure us.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
As I am an honest man he looks pale, art thou
sick, or angry?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
What, courage man: what though care killed a cat,
thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
Sir, I shall meet your wit in the career, and you
charge it against me, I pray you choose another subject

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Nay then give him another staff, this last was broke
cross.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
By this light, he changes more and more, I think
he be angry indeed.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: If he be, he knows how to turn his girdle.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Shall I speak a word in your ear?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: God bless me from a challenge.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
You are a villain, I jest not, I will make it good
how you dare, with what you dare, and when you dare: do
me right, or I will protest your cowardice: you have killed a
sweet Lady, and her death shall fall heavy on you, let me
hear from you.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Well I will meet you, so I may have good cheer.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: What, a feast, a feast?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
I faith I thank him he hath bid me to a calves head
and a capon, the which if I do not carve most curiously, say my
knife is naught, shall I not find a woodcock too?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Sir your wit ambles well, it goes easily.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
I will tell thee how Beatrice praised thy wit the other
day: I said thou hadst a fine wit, true said she, a fine little one:
no said I, a great wit: right syas she, a great gross one: nay said
I, a good wit, just said she, it hurts nobody: nay said I, the
gentleman is wise: certain said she, a wise gentleman: nay said I, he
hath the tongues: that I believe said she, for he swore a thing
to me on monday night, which he forswore on tuesday
morning, there is a double tongue theirs two tongues, thus did she
an hour together trans-shape thy particular virtues, yet at last
she concluded with a sigh, thou wast the properest man in Italy.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
For the which she wept heartily and said she cared
not.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Yea that she did, but yet for all that, and if she did
not hate him deadly, she would love him dearly, the old man's
daughter told us all.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
All all, and moreover, God saw him when he was
hid in the garden.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
But when shall we set the savage bulls horns on
the sensible Benedicks head?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
Yea and text under-neath, here dwells Benedick the
married man.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
Fare you well, boy, you know my mind, I will leave
you now to your gossip-like humour, you break jests as
braggarts do their blades, which God be thanked hurt not: my
Lord, for your many courtesies I thank you, I must discontinue
your company, your brother the bastard is fled from Messina:
you have among you, killed a sweet and innocent lady: for
my Lord Lack-beard, there he and I shall meet, and till then
peace be with him.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: He is in earnest.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p:
In most profound earnest, and I will warrant you, for
the love of Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: And hath challenged thee.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: Most sincerely.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
What a pretty thing man is, when he goes in his
doublet and hose, and leaves off his wit!

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p:
He is then a Giant to an Ape, but then is an Ape a
Doctor to such a man.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
But soft you, let me be, pluck up my heart, and be
sad, did he not say my brother was fled?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Come you sir, if justice cannot tame you, she shall
never weigh more reasons in her balance, nay, and you be a
cursing hypocrite once, you must be looked to.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
How now, two of my brothers men bound? Borachio
one.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: Hearken after their offence my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Officers, what offence have these men done?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Marry sir, they have committed false report, moreover
they have spoken untruths, secondarily they are slanders,
sixth and lastly, they have belied a Lady, thirdly they have
verified unjust things, and to conclude, they are lying knaves.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
First I ask thee what they have done, thirdly I
ask thee what is their offence, sixth and lastly why they are
committed, and to conclude, what you lay to their charge.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Rightly reasoned, and in his own division, and by
my troth there is one meaning well suited.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Who have you offended masters, that you are thus
bound to your answer? this learned Constable is too cunning
to be understood, what is your offence?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Sweet prince, let me go no farther to mine answer:
do you hear me, and let this Count kill me: I have deceived
even your very eyes: what your wisdoms could not discover,
these shallow fools have brought to light, who in the night
overheard me confessing to this man, how Don Iohn your
brother incensed me to slander the Lady Hero, how you were
brought into the orchard, and saw me court Margaret in
Heroes garments, how you disgraced her when you should marry
her: my villainy they have upon record, which I had rather seal
with my death, than repeat over to my shame: the lady is dead
upon mine and my masters false accusation: and briefly, I
desire nothing but the reward of a villain.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Runs not this speech like iron through your
blood?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: I have drunk poison whiles he uttered it.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: But did my brother set thee on to this?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Yea, and paid me richly for the practise of it.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: He is composed and framed of treachery,
And fled he is upon this villainy.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Sweet Hero, now thy image doth appear
In the rare semblance that I loved it first.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Come, bring away the plaintiffs, by this time our
sexton hath reformed Signior Leonato of the matter: and
masters, do not forget to specify when time and place shall serve,
that I am an ass.

sp.speaker: Con. 2
sp.p:
Here, here comes master Signior Leonato, and the
sexton too.

div2.stage: Enter Leonato, his brother, and the Sexton.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Which is the villain? let me see his eyes,
That when I note another man like him,
I may avoid him: which of these is he?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: If you would know your wronger, look on me.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Art thou the slave that with thy breath hast killed
Mine innocent child?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Yea, even I alone.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: No, not so villain, thou beliest thyself,
Here stand a pair of honourable men,
A third is fled that had a hand in it:
I thank you Princes for my daughters death,
Record it with your high and worthy deeds,
It was bravely done, if you bethink you of it.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: I know not how to pray your patience,
Yet I must speak, choose your revenge yourself,
Impose me to what penance your invention
Can lay upon my sin, yet sinned I not,
But in mistaking.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: By my soul nor I,
And yet to satisfy this good old man,
I would bend under any heavy weight,
That he will enjoin me to.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: I cannot bid you bid my daughter live,
That were impossible, but I pray you both,
Possess the people in Messina here,
How innocent she died, and if your love
Can labour aught in sad invention,
Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb,
And sing it to her bones, sing it tonight:
Tomorrow morning come you to my house,
And since you could not be my son in law,
Be yet my nephew: my brother hath a daughter,
Almost the copy of my child that is dead,
And she alone is heir to both of us,
Give her the right you should have given her cousin,
And so dies my revenge.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: O noble sir!
Your over kindness doth wring tears from me,
I do embrace your offer and dispose,
For henceforth of poor Claudio.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Tomorrow then I will expect your coming,
Tonight I take my leave, this naughty man
Shall face to face be brought to Margaret,
Who I believe was packed in all this wrong,
Hired to it by your brother.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: No by my soul she was not,
Nor knew not what she did when she spoke to me,
But always hath been just and virtuous,
In anything that I do know by her.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Moreover sir, which indeed is not under white and
black, this plaintiff here, the offender, did call me ass, I
beseech you let it be remembered in his punishment, and also
the watch heard them talk of one Deformed, they say he
wears a key in his ear and a lock hanging by it, and borrows
money in Gods name, the which he hath used so long, and never
paid, that now men grow hard hearted and will lend nothing
for Gods sake: pray you examine him upon that point.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p: I thank thee for thy care and honest pains.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Your worship speaks like a most thankful and
reverent youth, and I praise God for you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: There is for thy pains.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: God save the foundation.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Go, I discharge thee of thy prisoner, and I thank
thee.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
I leave an arrant knave with your worship, which I
beseech your worship to correct yourself, for the example of
others: God keep your worship, I wish your worship well,
God restore you to health, I humbly give you leave to depart
and if a merry meeting may be wished, God prohibit it: come
neighbour.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Until tomorrow morning, Lords, farewell.

sp.speaker: Brot.
sp.p: Farewell my lords, we look for you tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: We will not fail.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Tonight I will mourn with Hero.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.p:
Bring you these fellows on, we will talk with
Margaret, how her acquaintance grew with this lewd fellow.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
Pray thee sweet mistress Margaret, deserve well at
my hands, by helping me to the speech of Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Will you then write me a sonnet in praise of my beauty?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
In so high a style Margaret, that no man living shall
come over it, for in most comely truth thou deservest it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
To have no man come over me, why shall I always
keep below stairs.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Thy wit is as quick as the grey-hounds mouth, it
catches.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
And yours, as blunt as the Fencers foils, which hit,
but hurt not.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
A most manly wit Margaret, it will not hurt a
woman: and so I pray thee call Beatrice, I give thee the bucklers.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
Give us the swords, we have bucklers of our
own.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
If you use them Margaret, you must put in the
pikes with a vice, and they are dangerous weapons for
maids.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Well, I will call Beatrice to you, who I think hath
legs.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
And therefore will come. The God of love that sits
above, and knows me, and knows me, how pitiful I
deserve. I mean in singing, but in loving, Leander the good
swimmer, Troilus the first employer of panders, and a whole
book full of these quondam carpet-mongers, whose names
yet run smoothly in the even rode of a blank verse, why
they were never so truly turned over and over as my poor self
in love: marry I cannot show it in rime, I have tried, I can find
out no rime to Lady but baby, an innocent rime: for scorn,
horn, a hard rime: for school fool, a babbling rime: very
ominous endings, no, I was not born under a riming planet,
nor I cannot woo in festival terms: sweet Beatrice wouldst
thou come when I called thee?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Yea signior, and depart when you bid me.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: O stay but till then.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Then, is spoken: fare you well now, and yet ere I go,
let me go with that I came, which is, with knowing what
hath past between you and Claudio.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Only foul words, and thereupon I will kiss thee.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Foul words is but foul wind, and foul wind is but
foul breath, and foul breath is noisome, therefore I will depart
unkissed.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Thou hast frighted the word out of his right sense,
so forcible is thy wit, but I must tell thee plainly, Claudio undergoes
my challenge, and either I must shortly hear from him,
or I will subscribe him a coward, and I pray thee now tell me,
for which of my bad parts didst thou first fall in love with me?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
For them all together, which maintained so politic
a state of evil, that they will not admit any good part to
intermingle with them: but for which of my good parts did you first
suffer love for me?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Suffer love! a good epithet, I do suffer love indeed,
for I love thee against my will.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
In spite of your heart I think, alas poor heart, if
you spite it for my sake, I will spite it for yours, for I will never
love that which my friend hates.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Thou and I are too wise to woo peaceably.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
It appears not in this confession, there is not one wise
man among twenty that will praise himself.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
An old, an old instance Beatrice, that lived in the time
of good neighbours, if a man do not erect in this age his own
tomb ere he dies, he shall live no longer in monument, than
the bell rings, and the widow weeps.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: And how long is that think you?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Question, why an hour in clamour and a quarter in
rheum, therefore is it most expedient for the wise, if Don
worm (his conscience) find no impediment to the contrary, to
be the trumpet of his own virtues, as I am to myself so much
for praising myself, who I myself will bear witness is praise
worthy, and now tell me, how doth your cousin?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Very ill.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: And how do you?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Very ill too.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Serve God, love me, and mend, there will I leave you
too, for here comes one in haste.

sp.speaker: Vrsula
sp.p:
Madam, you must come to your uncle, yonder is old
coil at home, it is proved my Lady Hero hath been falsely
accused, the Prince and Claudio mightily abused, and Don Iohn
is the author of all, who is fled and gone: will you come presently?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Will you go hear this news signior?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I will live in thy heart, die in thy lap, and be buried in
thy eyes: and moreover, I will go with thee to thy uncles.

div2.stage: Enter Claudio, Prince, and three or foure with tapers.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: Is this the monument of Leonato?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: It is my Lord.

sp.speaker: Epitaph.
sp.l: Done to death by slanderous tongues,
Was the Hero that here lies:
Death in guerdon of her wrongs,
Gives her fame which never dies:
So the life that died with shame,
Lives in death with glorious fame.
Hang thou there upon the tomb,
Praising her when I am dead.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.p: Now music sound and sing your solemn hymn.

sp.speaker: Song
sp.l: Pardon goddess of the night,
Those that slew thy virgin knight,
For the which with songs of woe,
Round about her tomb they goe:
Midnight assist our moan, help us to sigh and groan.
Heavily heavily.
Graves yawn and yield your dead,
Till death be uttered,
Heavily heavily.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p:
Now unto thy bones good night, yearly will I do this
right.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Good morrow masters, put your torches out,
The wolves have prayed, and look, the gentle day
Before the wheels of Phoebus, round about
Dapples the drowsy East with spots of grey:
Thanks to you all, and leave us, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Good morrow masters, each his several way.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Come let us hence, and put on other weeds,
And then to Leonatoes we will go.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: And Hymen now with luckier issue speeds,
Than this for whom we rendered up this woe.

div2.stage: Enter Leonato, Benedick, Margaret Vrsula, old man, Frier, Hero.

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.l: Did I not tell you she was innocent?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: So are the Prince and Claudio who accused her,
Upon the error that you heard debated:
But Margaret was in some fault for this,
Although against her will as it appears,
In the true course of all the question.

sp.speaker: Old
sp.l: Well, I am glad that all things sorts so well.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.l: And so am I, being else by faith enforced
To call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Well daughter, and you gentlewomen all,
Withdraw into a chamber by yourselves,
And when I send for you come hither masked:
The Prince and Claudio promised by this hour
To visit me, you know your office brother,
You must be father to your brothers daughter,
And give her to young Claudio.

sp.speaker: Old
sp.l: Which I will do with confirmed countenance.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.l: Frier, I must entreat your pains, I think.

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.l: To do what Signior?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.l: To bind me, or undo me, one of them:
Signior Leonato, truth it is good Signior,
Your niece regards me with an eye of favour.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That eye my daughter lent her, it is most true.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.l: And I do with an eye of love requite her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The sight whereof I think you had from me,
From Claudio and the Prince, but what is your will?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.l: Your answer sir is enigmatical,
But for my will, my will is, your good will
May stand with ours, this day to be conjoined,
In the state of honourable marriage,
In which (good Frier) I shall desire your help.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: My heart is with your liking.

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.l: And my help.
Here comes the Prince and Claudio.

div2.stage: Enter Prince, and Claudio, and two or three other.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Good morrow to this fair assembly.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Good morrow Prince, good morrow Claudio:
We here attend you, are you yet determined,
Today to marry with my brothers daughter?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I will hold my mind were she an Ethiope.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Call her forth brother, here is the Frier ready.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Good morrow Bened. why what is the matter?
That you have such a February face,
So full of frost, of storm, and cloudiness.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I think he thinks upon the savage bull:
Tush fear not man, we will tip thy horns with gold,
And all Europa shall rejoice at thee,
As once Europa did at lusty Ioue,
When he would play the noble beast in love.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Bull Ioue sir had an amiable low,
And some such strange bull leapt your fathers cow,
And got a calf in that same noble feat,
Much like to you, for you have just his bleat.

div2.stage: Enter brother, Hero, Beatrice, Margaret, Vrsula.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: For this I owe you: here comes other reckonings.
Which is the Lady I must seize upon?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: This same is she, and I do give you her.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Why then she is mine, sweet, let me see your face.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: No that you shall not till you take her hand,
Before this Frier, and swear to marry her.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Give me your hand before this holy Frier,
I am your husband if you like of me.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: And when I lived I was your other wife,
And when you loved, you were my other husband.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Another Hero.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: Nothing certainer.
One Hero died defiled, but I do live,
And surely as I live, I am a maid.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: The former Hero, Hero that is dead.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: She died my Lord, but whiles her slander lived.

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.l: All this amazement can I qualify,
When after that the holy rites are ended,
I will tell you largely of fair Heroes death,
Mean time let wonder seem familiar,
And to the chapel let us presently.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Soft and fair Frier, which is Beatrice?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: I answer to that name, what is your will?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Do not you love me?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Why no, no more than reason.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Why then your uncle, and the prince, and Claudio,
Have been deceived, they swore you did.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Do not you love me?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Troth no, no more than reason.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Why then my cousin Margaret and Vrsula
Are much deceived, for they did swear you did.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: They swore that you were almost sick for me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: They swore that you were well-nigh dead for me.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: It is no such matter, then you do not love me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: No truly, but in friendly recompense.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Come cousin, I am sure you love the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: And I will be sworn upon it that he loves her,
For here is a paper written in his hand,
A halting sonnet of his own pure brain,
Fashioned to Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: And here is another,
Writ in my cousins hand, stolen from her pocket,
Containing her affection unto Benedicke.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
A miracle, here is our own hands against our hearts:
come, I will have thee, but by this light I take thee for pity.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I would not deny you, but by this good day, I yield
upon great persuasion, and partly to save your life, for I was
told, you were in a consumption.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Peace I will stop your mouth.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: How dost thou Benedicke the married man?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I will tell thee what prince: a college of wit-crackers
cannot flout me out of my humour, dost thou think I care for
a Satire or an Epigram? no, if a man will be beaten with
brains, he shall wear nothing handsome about him: in brief,
since I do purpose to marry, I will think nothing to any
purpose that the world can say against it, and therefore never flout
at me, for what I have said against it: for man is a giddy thing,
and this is my conclusion: for thy part Claudio, I did think
to have beaten thee, but in that thou art like to be my kinsman,
live unbruised, and love my cousin.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
I had well hoped thou wouldst have denied Beatrice,
that I might have cudgeled thee out of thy single life, to make
thee a double dealer, which out of question thou wilt be, if my
cousin do not look exceeding narrowly to thee.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Come, come, we are friends, let us have a dance ere we
are married, that we may lighten our own hearts, and our wives
heels.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: We will have dancing afterwards.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
First, of my word, therefore play music, Prince,
thou art sad, get thee a wife, get thee a wife, there is no staff
more reverent than one tipped with horn.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: My Lord, your brother Iohn is taken in flight,
And brought with armed men back to Messina.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Think not on him till tomorrow, I will devise thee
brave punishments for him: strike up Pipers.
